snippet: Egyptian and Israeli officials contradicted each other’s accounts of how or even whether their two presidents had communicated.
abstract: Egyptian Pres Mohamed Morsi denies having sent a conciliatory letter to Israeli Pres Shimon Peres, reversing what had at first been seen as evidence that Egypt's new Muslim Brotherhood-led government would maintain cordial ties with Israel; confusion underscores the delicacy of relations between the two countries, which have historically maintained a peaceful if frosty entente.

byline.original: By ISABEL KERSHNER and ELISABETH BUMILLER
byline.contributor: Isabel Kershner reported from Jerusalem, and Elisabeth Bumiller from Cairo. Mayy El Sheikh and Kareem Fahim contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Egyptian and Israeli officials contradicted each other’s accounts of how or even whether their two presidents had communicated.

headline.main: Uncertainty Over Letter Underscores Delicate Ties
headline.print_headline: Uncertainty Over Letter Underscores Delicate Ties
